103421.comment:
Please do not waste time and taxpayers money to send us backwards, when other amazing world cities are moving forward with pedestrian infrastructure. Its embarrassing. Its dangerous.
This feels like a sick joke being played on the good people of Toronto. My 71 year old father rides his bicycle in the city and I don’t want to see him crushed to death by an F150.
Thoughtful city planning is the way to move forward; more bike lanes, more pedestrian streets, more third places. Less big ugly roadways.  We need to work together to build better public transit and pedestrian corridors, not the other way around.
What happens when we waste all this energy to remove bike lanes and nothing changes, or even get worse? The next government in power spends our money to reverse the damage… take a look at Europe and try to learn something. SMH.

103422.comment:
I bike to work 9 months of the year, downtown from the Junction Triangle. The Bloor bikelane has been one of the greatest additions to my safety the city could have possibly undertaken.
I will still ride to work, daily, but if the lane is removed I will do so in traffic. I don't ride fast, and I'll ride even slower on account of greater fear for my safety.
I'm not sure how me, riding slowly, will help drivers get where they are going faster. I do know that me, riding in a seperate bikelane, allows cars to dictate the speed of traffic.
If you want to help drivers, keep bikelanes.

103425.comment:
I think the provincial government should try to cut red tape and let muncipalities decide how their streets should look.
Moreover, it should be easier to build bike lanes than car lanes. We want to get more people out of cars and into active transportation. Even if bike lanes cause congestion to cars – and I think this is not borne out by any studies – it would still be preferable to build more bike and pedestrian infrastructure. It's the car drivers that are causing air and noise pollution and who are involved in the deaths of approximately1,000 Ontarians every year.

103426.comment: Bike infrastructure is a critical component of the transition to a low carbon/carbon neutral planet. Dedicated bike infrastructure REDUCES traffic rather than increasing it, and typically are less costly than vehicle infrastructure is to maintain. If the provincial government is serious about reducing traffic for drivers, then they need to provide drivers with safe alternatives. Bogging down municipalities with the cost of studies and then delays as their requests are reviewed is - in my opinion - the worst way to better road congestion and manage traffic. After all, what happens to the people who use the lanes getting removed? They're going to keep biking but now they're sharing the road rather than having their own. Traffic and cost concerns aside, removing bike lanes will make roads slightly more dangerous for drivers and far, FAR more dangerous for bikers.

103427.comment: Urban bike lanes reduce car traffic, make roads safer for everyone and increase income for businesses. Every study in every city in the world (including in Toronto) confirms this. We need more bike lanes, and more public transit. The lack of bike lanes, lack of transit, and antiquated investment in increasing car traffic is embarrassing but more importantly, it is dangerous and economically, socially and environmentally damaging.

103429.comment:
Removing bike lanes in Toronto will quite obviously make traffic worse, most of the people who bike would need change to driving, making traffic worse. For those who do not have the option to drive as they may not be able to afford a car or have other restrictions, the roads will become more dangerous. Removing bike lanes will almost certainly get people killed.
This proposal morally disgusting, endangering lives while prioritizing saving a few minutes of time (which won’t even happen regardless) for those in cars.

103430.comment: I think this phase is a mistake in two regards: micromanaging cities creates extra work and costs for the provincial government. It's not been shown that this will generate anywhere near the amount of money it will cost to pay for the worker-hours too implement and oversee this system. Even if it did, the province should not be dictating to the city how to manage its affairs. The locals should have the right to manage their own city.

103431.comment: I am strongly against this proposal.  Biking infrastructure is key to a promoting a healthy and eco friendly lifestyle, something the government should be promoting not destroying.   I have voted for Ford in the past because I agreed with majority of his policies, if this goes through consider mine and my families votes gone.

103432.comment:
As someone who doesn’t own a car, biking is my primary mode of transportation, and it’s essential for my daily commute. Doug Ford’s proposal to remove bike lanes at Bloor St and University Avenue is not only baffling but also a step backward in making our cities more sustainable and accessible. These bike lanes are crucial for safety and mobility, and removing them would make cycling more dangerous while pushing people back into cars, worsening traffic congestion and pollution. I can’t fathom why we’d dismantle infrastructure that promotes healthier, more eco-friendly transportation.
Instead of removing bike lanes, we should be focusing on improving the quality of public transit and active transportation options like cycling. Investing in better transit and cycling infrastructure is key to reducing congestion and making our cities more livable. Quality public transit should be the priority, ensuring that people have reliable, efficient, and accessible alternatives to driving. By supporting these modes of transportation, we can reduce car dependence, cut down on emissions, and create a more connected, sustainable city.
It’s hard to imagine Doug Ford truly understanding the importance of bike lanes when it seems like he doesn’t personally experience what it’s like to navigate the city by bike. Biking requires safe infrastructure, and without it, people are forced into cars or unsafe situations on the road. If more decision-makers regularly relied on active transportation like cycling, they’d see firsthand how vital it is to create safe, accessible spaces for all modes of transport—not just for those behind the wheel.

103435.comment:
Removing bike lanes is counter to what research suggests we should be doing, it is against what the city wants (why is the entire province deciding on what happens in one city), and is otherwise a significant loss of time and resources.
Studies clearly show that bike lanes reduce congestion and (obviously) emissions,  not increase it: https://www.cbc.ca/news/science/bike-lanes-impacts-1.7358319
"Studies from around the world show bike lanes ease congestion, reduce emissions and are a boon to businesses"
Street parking, on the other hand, uses up an entire lane for a handful of vehicles to idle for hours. That would likely be a better use of resources than reversing progress on already built bike lanes.

103437.comment: I do not think this proposal is helpful for congestion, and truthfully seems more like Doug Ford is interested in punishing Toronto. I do not want my tax dollars to be spent ripping out bike lanes that have JUST been put in. More construction will exacerbate the issue of traffic, and there are other ways to mitigate congestion in the city, but that is also Toronto’s responsibility as a city. This is a bill that seems to also be trying to push in other items that are not helpful to Toronto, and especially others in Ontario. I  distressed to see legislation like this being tabled.

103440.comment: We need more safe bike routes, not fewer. Every person should feel safe while riding their bike inside or between cities in southern Ontario. I am sick of seeing news articles every week about yet another person mown down by careless automobile drivers. I am sick of being forced to drive, and living in a society that forces others to drive, because biking is unsafe and we have no alternatives. No road expansions. Build bike and transit now.

103442.comment:

1) Stop wasting my tax dollars with this nonsense! I pay ridiculous amounts of taxes to the province personally and from my business, and I expect them to be put to productive use, which is NOT THIS. This province is hurting for housing and healthcare, not your obsession with bikes.
2) As a driver, I want bikes in dedicated bike lanes. I do NOT want to have to worry about them jumping around traffic! Keeping them in dedicated bike lanes ensures safety for everyone and keeps their erratic behavior away from cars. Reality is we will keep getting more bike riders, time to adapt.

103443.comment:

This government claims to be opposed to red tape and is introducing more unnecessarily. This government claims to care about people's time and improving people's commute and is trying to pass legislation that will make things worse. 103445.comment:
